items.body_markdown:
I was wondering if it's possible to change Woocommerce Related Products to use last level of category instead of just first level.
For example check this [Product Category tree]:

> Wearables
> 
>       --Glasses
> 
>       --Watches
> 
> Uncategorized

As you can see, there are two categories (Glasses and Watches) that are children of another category (Wearables). Now let's imagine we have these as products:

> Name      | Categories
> 
> Product 1 | Wearables, Glasses
> 
> Product 2 | Wearables, Glasses
> 
> Product 3 | Wearables, Watches

In this example, what woocommerce do to pull out the related products is like this:

    Product 1 <=> Product 2 <=> Product 3

Because all of them are in category "Wearables".

Now my question is, how do I change that so only "Product 1" and "Product 2" are related based on "Glasses" Category?
Note that this example is only 2 level deep, the solution should work for any levels.

Thanks in advance.

items.body:
I am designing a simple blog project using sqlalchemy and flask. In my index page i load the list of available posts in my database in descending order sorted by date of posting . Below is my code for index.html :

  {% extends "base.html" %}
  {% from "show_links.html" import show_flash_messages %}
  {% block title %}
  <title>Home page</title>
  {% endblock %}

  {% block jqueryscripts %}
    <script>

      });
    </script>
  {% endblock %}

  {% block content %}
  <br/>
  <div class="container">
      <div class="row">
        <div class="col-sm-6 mx-auto">
          {{ show_flash_messages() }}
          {% if posts %}
          {% for post in posts.items %}

              <h4 class="post-title">
                {{ post.title }}
              </h4>

          {% endfor %}
          <hr>

              {% if posts.has_prev %}
                    <a style="background-color:teal; padding:10px 8px;" class="btn btn-default float-left" href="{{ url_for('posts.index',page=posts.prev_num) }}">Newer Posts →</a>

              {% endif %}
              {% if posts.has_next %}
                    <a style="background-color:teal;padding:10px 8px;" class="btn btn-default float-right" href="{{ url_for('posts.index',page=posts.next_num) }}">Older Posts →</a>
              {% else %}
                    <button style="background-color:teal;padding:10px 8px;" class="btn btn-default float-right disabled">Older Posts →</button>
              {% endif %}
          {% else %}

              <h4 class="post-title">
                No post to display. Add a new post !
              </h4>
          </div>
          {% endif %}
        </div>

    </div>
  {% endblock %}

Below is the code for my index route :

@posts_blueprint.route('/')
@posts_blueprint.route('/index')

def index(page=1):
    posts = []
    added_posts = Post.get_all_posts(page)

and below is the code for my get_all_posts function:

class Post(db.Model):

So here i am doing pagination at sqlalchemy level and then displaying them with the click of the buttons.

Now this is refreshing the index page supplying additional page numbers to it.

Now i dont think this is the ideal way to do it since this would refresh the entire page which would make it slow.

So i was thinking of just refreshing the posts(sqlalchemy) object using Ajax or jquery .

Is this even possible to do ?

Can someone please throw some light.

The scenario: domain A hosts the asp.net webforms that is accessed from domain B across the internet(firewall rule etc in place, https on webforms). Domain B also has an instance of ADFS 3.0 and the AD

When a user connects to the webforms on domain A from Domain B, it needs to authenticate with the ADFS 3.0 server on domain A and then decide to either let him through or redirect to login screen.

I have the theoretical knowledge from reading how to configure ADFS server for the relying party etc. my problem is the code. How, in my webforms do I get his browser token and authenticate it on domain B(access a few of his claims like email and name)

I am a total newbie to ADFS question and I would appreciate some sample code and/or pointers or links. 

Thank you in advance

items.title: When are you required to use reacts prevState?
items.body:
Lets say whe have this state

state = {
  name: 'Daniel',
  fruits: {
    one: 'Banana',
    two: 'Apple'
  }
}

I could update this with

this.setState({
  fruits: {
    ...this.state.fruits,
    one: 'Pineapple'
  }
})

or i could do

this.setState(prevState => ({
  fruits: {
    ...prevState.fruits,
    one: 'Pineapple'
  }
}))

I understand that if you have a counter that should be incremented, it would be a good idea to make sure you're incrementing from the previous state. But if we are changing a name and don't care about the previous name. Is there any benefit of using prevState in that case?

Do you only need to use prevState if you're actually calculating something based on the previous state? In this case, we are spreading the fruits object. Could this object been changed in another call simultaniously and the version without prevState overriding it? (Do i always have to use prevState when handling objects in state?)

items.title: Android navigation, from fragment activity and back again
items.body:
I think this question was asked many times, but no other question somehow answers my issue. The problem is very simple. I have an activity with fragments

protected void onCreate(Bundle savedInstanceState) {
        super.onCreate(savedInstanceState);
        setContentView(R.layout.activity_main_tabbed);

        toolbar = (Toolbar) findViewById(R.id.toolbar);
        setSupportActionBar(toolbar);

        viewPager = (ViewPager) findViewById(R.id.viewpager);
        setupViewPager(viewPager);

        tabLayout = (TabLayout) findViewById(R.id.tabs);
        tabLayout.setupWithViewPager(viewPager);
    }
private void setupViewPager(ViewPager viewPager) {
        adapter = new ViewPagerAdapter(getSupportFragmentManager());
        adapter.addFragment(new Fragment1(), "1");
        adapter.addFragment(new Fragment2(), "2");
        adapter.addFragment(new Fragment3(), "3");
        viewPager.setAdapter(adapter);
    }

so far so good, I can navigate to fragment 2 and there I can start a new activity

Intent intent = new Intent(activity, AnotherActivity.class);
startActivity(intent);

Then, when I finish doing stuff in this anotheractivity, can use the back button to return to my activity with fragments. But then, it always starts with fragment1 instead of fragment2, the one I started the anotheractivity. How can I make it return to the original state with fragment2 active?

I tried onSaveStateInstance and PendingActivity, but both in vain.

items.title: converting timestamp to MM DD,YYYY and vice versa with out any npm
items.body:
I have written below microservice to convert unix timestamp to a format like Dec 01,2017 and vice versa and deployed here timestamp

Is their any better way to do this with out third party NPM

var path = require('path');
var express = require('express');
var app = express();
var bodyparser = require('body-parser');


app.route('/:date')
    .get(function(req, res) {
        // res.sendFile(process.cwd() + '/views/index.html');
        var unix = null,
            naturaldate = null;
        //console.log(parseInt(timestamp),timestamp)
        let timestamp = req.params.date;
        if (!isNaN(timestamp)) {
            let parsetime = new Date(parseInt(timestamp))
            console.log(parsetime);
            if (parsetime == 'Invalid Date') {
                console.log("got invalid date")
                send_response(null, null, res);
            }
            let parsenaturaldate = parsetime.toDateString().split(" ").slice(1);
            let year = parsenaturaldate.splice(2, 0, ',');
            year = parsenaturaldate.splice(1, 0, ' ')
            naturaldate = parsenaturaldate.join("")
            console.log(naturaldate)
            unix = parseInt(timestamp)
            send_response(unix, naturaldate, res);
        } else {
            unix = Date.parse(timestamp);

            if (!isNaN(unix))
                naturaldate = timestamp
            else
                send_response(null, null, res);
            send_response(unix, naturaldate, res);
        }
    })

function send_response(unix, naturaldate, res) {
    console.log(unix, naturaldate)
    res.json({
        "unix": unix,
        "natural": naturaldate
    })
}

app.listen(8083 || process.env.PORT, () => {

})
